race.name: Crooked Gravel
race.tagline: Colorado mountain gravel in Winter Park with high altitude climbing.

climate.description: High altitude with variable mountain conditions. Afternoon thunderstorms possible.

terrain.surface: Mountain gravel roads with significant elevation. High altitude terrain with challenging climbing.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Colorado mountain event. High altitude and significant climbing but regional field and infrastructure.

biased_opinion.summary: Crooked Gravel offers a genuine Colorado mountain gravel challenge with high altitude and significant climbing. Winter Park is a beautiful mountain resort town with good amenities. The course is challenging with 6000 feet of climbing at 8000-10000+ feet elevation. It's a well-organized regional event with a moderate field. The main appeal is the mountain setting and altitude challenge.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Colorado mountain gravel race with genuine altitude and climbing challenges. Worth it for Colorado cyclists or those seeking a mountain gravel experience near Denver. Not a destination race for distant travelers, but a good regional mountain event.

final_verdict.one_liner: Regional Colorado mountain gravel with high altitude and significant climbing.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Colorado or the Front Range and want a mountain gravel challenge‚Äîyes, it's a well-organized event with genuine altitude and climbing. If you're traveling from far away‚Äîthere are more prestigious mountain events elsewhere.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Colorado mountain events: Leadville 100, Steamboat Gravel. For similar regional mountain vibes: other Front Range events.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: 62 miles of Colorado mountain gravel at 8000-10000+ feet.
marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional mountain event in Winter Park with 6000 feet of climbing.

logistics.explanation: Packet pickup Friday 5-7pm at Terrain Taco plus Saturday morning registration offers flexibility. The Exploring the Rockies blogger found the start well-organized with 350 riders getting a police escort down CO-40 through Winter Park, though he noted "the end of the race was somewhat anti-climatic" with no official welcoming committee at the bike path finish.

length.explanation: The 67-mile distance proved challenging with aid stations spaced 28 miles apart between stops. One rider noted being "still in very good spirits" at mile 40 Aid #2, saying "nothing up until this point was all that physically exhausting," but the final 27 miles broke many riders on the endless CR-50 climb. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Course shifts from smooth gravel to "teeth chattering rough" washboard descents at 25-30mph. One rider described it as "where I was officially introduced to what a gravel race is all about ‚Äì those who can handle the downhills and those who can't," noting the technical challenge of "flying down a rough dirt road with no suspension." Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: The main climb on CR-50 delivers "2,500 ft of vertical over 13 miles" with the first climb topping out "shy of 10,400 ft." One rider called it "basically 11 miles of a 5-10% grade‚Ä¶..for eternity" along The Blue Ridge, forcing a goal change from sub-5 hours to just staying on the bike. More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score.

climate.explanation: August temperatures hit 70-75¬∞F during the race with biting flies that "almost broke" one rider who had to maintain pace "quick enough to keep the flies from overwhelming me." Official warnings note afternoon thunderstorms are common with unpredictable mountain weather requiring rain gear. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Starting at 8,700 feet with climbing to 10,400+ feet creates sustained oxygen debt. One rider noted "I'd still recommend low gears. Climbing at elevation is a challenge," while another found "riding on flattish gravel/dirt was more difficult than riding on a slight uphill on paved asphalt" due to thin air effects. Higher altitude racing, comparable to SBT GRVL.

adventure.explanation: Course travels through remote terrain along Beaver Creek and Keyser Creek sections, with the Blue Ridge providing "massive, never ending ridge" views. Miles of forest roads transition to "wide-open, smooth-running dirt roads that you'll swear are smoother than pavement" before returning to technical washboard sections.

prestige.explanation: Strambecco calls it one of Colorado's best gravel events, but race reports show a 5:03 finish time as competitive, suggesting modest field depth. The event traces back to Ron Kiefel's original "Crooked Roubaix" challenge, though current field strength appears regional rather than destination-level competition.

race_quality.explanation: The Ride Collective and Gemini Adventures provide solid execution with police escort starts and aid stations stocked with "sports gels, Precision electrolyte drink, PB&J rolls." However, the timed section ends mysteriously "back somewhere along the Crooked Creek dirt road" with an anticlimactic bike path finish into town.

experience.explanation: High alpine terrain delivers dramatic scenery shifts from lush Beaver Creek valleys to exposed Blue Ridge climbing. Course provides "meandering ascents through aspen and pine forests" with technical descents, though one finisher noted the experience as "deceptively challenging" despite the mountain beauty.

community.explanation: The 350-rider field includes "a good portion of whom looked like they were 'in it to win it'" according to race reports. Post-race features "free food, cold beer and live music" with Friday shakeout rides offering "$1 off pints" at Terrain Tacos, creating weekend festival atmosphere.

field_depth.explanation: Field size of 350 riders suggests healthy participation, but competitive depth appears modest with sub-5 hour finishing times considered strong performances. The addition of untimed recreational categories and e-bikes indicates organizers are expanding participation rather than focusing on elite competition. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Entry fees are completely absent from all race materials, making value impossible to assess properly. You get high-alpine terrain starting at 8,700 feet with nearly 2,000 feet of climbing on even the short course. Without knowing if this costs $75 or $175, it's a blind gamble on whether the Grand County gravel experience justifies the price tag.

expenses.explanation: Winter Park resort town pricing hits hard with recommended lodging at Winter Park Mountain Lodge and dining at Boca Winter Park. One rider invested in a dedicated gravel bike, noting the Canyon Grizl "was $1,000 cheaper than the Trek Checkpoint" for similar specs, showing equipment costs add up for this terrain. Higher total cost than Badlands.
